introducao: Vamos estudar novas palavras e expressões em inglês, com exemplos e explicações práticas.

Vocabulary.text: Expressão: Have a break — significa fazer uma pausa. Pode ser usada com adjetivos como 'brief' para indicar uma pausa curta.
I need to have a break.
Let’s have a brief break.
Do you want to have a break now?
Don’t you need a brief break?
Verbo: Burp — significa arrotar. É usado para descrever o som que fazemos depois de comer ou beber.
The baby burped after drinking milk.
He didn’t burp after lunch.
Did you just burp?
Don’t burp at the table!
Palavra: Downtown — significa centro da cidade. Refere-se à área principal onde há lojas, prédios e escritórios.
I work downtown.
We don’t live downtown.
Do you like going downtown on weekends?
Isn’t downtown always busy?
Expressão: Every single day — significa todos os dias, com ênfase. É usada para reforçar frequência.
She studies English every single day.
I don’t go to the gym every single day.
Do you drink coffee every single day?
Don’t you call your parents every single day?
Palavras: Inner city e suburb — Inner city é a parte central da cidade, geralmente mais antiga; suburb significa subúrbio ou bairro residencial afastado.
I live in the suburbs.
He works in the inner city.
Do you prefer living in the suburb or in the inner city?
Isn’t the inner city noisier than the suburb?
Expressão: Role play — significa dramatização ou simulação de situações. Muito usada em aulas de inglês.
Let’s do a role play.
We didn’t do a role play today.
Did you enjoy the role play activity?
Wasn’t that role play fun?
Verbo: Walk around — significa andar por aí ou passear.
I love to walk around the park.
We didn’t walk around the city last weekend.
Do you like to walk around downtown?
Why don’t we walk around the neighborhood?
Verbo: Chatted — é o passado de chat, que significa conversar informalmente.
We chatted for hours last night.
I didn’t chat with him yesterday.
Who did you chat with online?
Haven’t you chatted with her yet?
Expressão: Chess is a board game — quer dizer 'xadrez é um jogo de tabuleiro'.
Chess is a board game.
It’s not a card game; it’s a board game.
Do you play board games?
Isn’t chess a fun board game?
Palavra: Surroundings — significa arredores, ambiente ao redor de um lugar.
The hotel is beautiful, and the surroundings are amazing.
I don’t like these surroundings.
Are you comfortable with your surroundings?
Aren’t the surroundings peaceful here?
Expressão: Touristic spots — significa pontos turísticos.
We visited many touristic spots in Paris.
They didn’t go to all the touristic spots.
Did you enjoy the touristic spots?
Aren’t the touristic spots crowded?
Verbo: Cried — é o passado de cry, que significa chorar.
She cried after watching the movie.
He didn’t cry at all.
Did you cry during the film?
Why did the baby cry?
Expressão: Wave your hand — significa acenar com a mão.
Wave your hand to say hello.
Don’t wave your hand during class.
Did she wave her hand at you?
Who waved their hand first?
Palavra: Peck — significa dar um selinho ou bicada (de pássaro).
He gave her a quick peck on the cheek.
The bird pecked the bread.
Did you see the birds pecking the seeds?
Don’t peck too hard!
Palavra: Pepper — significa pimenta ou pimentão, dependendo do contexto.
Could you pass me the pepper, please?
I don’t like spicy pepper.
Do you grow peppers in your garden?
Isn’t black pepper good for health?
Palavra: Pickled — significa em conserva. Exemplo: pepinos em conserva = pickled cucumbers.
I love pickled cucumbers.
She doesn’t eat pickled onions.
Do you like pickled vegetables?
Aren’t pickled foods salty?

Instrucoesadicionais.text: Repita cada frase em voz alta. Tente usar essas palavras em frases próprias e imagine situações reais para fixar o vocabulário.
